author: By Clifford Krauss and Ivan Penn
title: Frozen turbines and surging demand prompt rolling blackouts in Texas.
description: The storm is taking a heavy toll on electric service in Texas. An estimated 2.6 million homes and businesses in the state had their power interrupted Sunday night and Monday morning because of storm damage or in rotating outages ordered by regulators.
content: The storm is taking a heavy toll on electric service in Texas. An estimated 2.6 million homes and businesses in the state had their power interrupted Sunday night and Monday morning because of storm damage or in rotating outages ordered by regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Parliament Rape Claim Roils Australian Government
description: A former government staff member said she had been made to choose between going to the police and keeping her job. Prime Minister Scott Morrison apologized.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — A former government staff member’s account of being raped in Australia’s Parliament building sent shock waves through the country’s halls of power on Monday, with the governing conservative party coming under intense criticism for the way it had handled the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Song
title: Lessons From a Homebody
description: South Korean YouTubers are sharing the simple pleasures of keeping a clean, organized and food-filled home.
content: In a video titled “Vlog That Makes You Want to Clean,” the South Korean YouTube creator Kim Sang-mi shows viewers how to tackle windowsill grime with a pair of chopsticks and a cleaning cloth, and how to disinfect the home using a mixture of soju and lemon slices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery, Campbell Robertson, Clifford Krauss and Marie Fazio
title: Icy Storm Barrels Across Central U.S., Leaving Millions Without Power
description: The snowstorm covered a huge part of the country, including states unaccustomed to slick roads and a deep freeze.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — A massive winter storm bulldozed its way across the southern and central United States on Monday, leaving millions of people without power amid freezing temperatures, sending vehicles crashing into one another on ice-glazed highways and bringing blizzard-like conditions to places where snowfall is usually the news from elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The fallout from Trump’s acquittal.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: In a Houston suburb, power failures are familiar. Crunching snow is not.
description: On Monday, Cheryl Rodriguez and her husband woke up to heaps of snow outside of their house, nestled in a neighborhood cul-de-sac in Conroe, Texas, about 40 miles north of Houston.
content: On Monday, Cheryl Rodriguez and her husband woke up to heaps of snow outside of their house, nestled in a neighborhood cul-de-sac in Conroe, Texas, about 40 miles north of Houston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Zuma Risks Arrest After Defying South Africa Corruption Inquiry
description: The former South African president, tainted by corruption scandals, refused to appear before an inquiry panel. The panel’s leader said he would seek an order to imprison Mr. Zuma for contempt.
content: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa whose nearly decade-long tenure was tainted by breathtaking corruption scandals, refused to appear before an inquiry panel Monday, raising the possibility that he would be imprisoned for contempt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Sax
title: Lessons From Virtual Kindergarten
description: The characteristics of a rhombus. The limits of parental authority. Gratitude.
content: “Is today a school day or the weekend?” my son asks, burrowing under our covers at 7 in the morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: There’s No ‘One Size Fits All’ Treatment for Asthma
description: A new set of guidelines recognizes the complexity in the interaction between a patient’s genetics and the environment.
content: Asthma may be a disease with one name. But experts say that unbeknown to most people who have it, it is not just one disease, nor is there a “one-size-fits-all” treatment for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: A Majestic Collar Worthy of a Superhero
description: Forged from gold and adorned with tourmaline cabochons in dark pink, grass green and sky blue, this Bulgari piece is all strength.
content: Whether sharply angled or gracefully curved, the outlines of modernity signal a purity, one unblemished by gimmicky gesture or fussy decoration. To be modern means, to some degree, baring oneself to the world. Case in point: Bulgari’s new three-ring collar, which evokes the 1980s, a time of exceptional postmodern verve, but also the otherworldly adornment of Cleopatra’s Egypt. The focus is three monumental, half-round, translucent stones — luscious tourmalines in pomegranate pink and palm green and a clear, Caribbean-blue aquamarine — cut en cabochon, a prehistoric color-enhancing lapidary technique that, despite feeling forever contemporary, actually predates faceted designs. Set on a pink-gold armature made in the house’s signature proto-industrial tubogas style — an unsoldered, flexible spiral inspired by early 20th-century underground gas pipes — the piece has a futuristic brio: the perfect amulet to encircle the neck of a superhero of any era, but especially our own. Price on request, (800) 285-4274.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Innovation, Not Trees. How Bill Gates Plans to Save the Planet.
description: He has billions to donate for crises from coronavirus to climate change, and more hope now that Trump is out of office.
content: Bill Gates is publishing a new book, “How to Avoid a Climate Disaster: The Solutions We Have and the Breakthroughs We Need.” In it, Mr. Gates, the Microsoft co-founder turned philanthropist, outlines a path to a zero emissions future. Apparently electric cars, vegan diets and tree-hugging won’t get us there. And neither will rockets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Two Tales of Disconnection, With One Cicada Cameo
description: Recorded on a Houston stage, “The Book of Magdalene” is theatrically intimate, while “Hotel Good Luck” gets caught up in digital trickery.
content: The sound of an actor’s footsteps on a stage. Remember that? The hollowness of it — wooden boards with just air underneath, one of a thousand sensations of theater that you don’t know you’ve missed until you hear it through your computer and your heart leaps, just a little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Morgan Wallen Holds Onto No. 1 Again Following Use of Racial Slur
description: The country star, who was condemned by the industry for his language, has only seen his album sales increase since the scandal.
content: Nearly two weeks and two apologies later, Morgan Wallen, the country singer who was promptly condemned by the music industry for using a racial slur, is still No. 1 on the charts — and his sales have increased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt, Simon Marks and Ronen Bergman
title: In a Dangerous Game of Cat and Mouse, Iran Eyes New Targets in Africa
description: Fifteen people arrested in Ethiopia were part of what American and Israeli officials said was a foiled Iranian plot against diplomats from the United Arab Emirates.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — When Ethiopia’s intelligence agency recently uncovered a cell of 15 people it said were casing the embassy of the United Arab Emirates, along with a cache of weapons and explosives, it claimed to have foiled a major attack with the potential to sow havoc in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: New Yorkers Rush to Get Vaccine After Eligibility Expands
description: The first of four million newly qualified people were vaccinated around the city and state on Monday, but many are still struggling to get an appointment.
content: The first of millions of New Yorkers with chronic health conditions lined up to receive the Covid-19 vaccine at sites around the city on Monday, a day after people inundated a state website and call center when they became eligible for the shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Pelosi Vows to Move Forward With Independent Inquiry Into Capitol Riot
description: Calls have grown among lawmakers for a 9/11 Commission-style panel to be established, which would most likely require legislation.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress will move to establish an independent commission to investigate the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, including facts “relating to the interference with the peaceful transfer of power,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 15, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 15, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 15, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The G.O.P. and Public Opinion
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Purely as a matter of political self-interest, congressional Republicans had some good reasons to abandon Donald Trump as the de facto leader of their party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Scientists Are Trying to Spot New Viruses Before They Cause Pandemics
description: Scientists want to build a weather system for viruses. It would require a big financial investment, plus buy-in from doctors, hospitals and blood banks.
content: Back in the summer, Dr. Michael Mina made a deal with a cold storage company. With many of its restaurant clients closed down, the firm had freezers to spare. And Dr. Mina, an epidemiologist at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, had a half-million vials of plasma from human blood coming to his lab from across the country, samples dating back to the carefree days of January 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Do Men Self-Care?
description: The beauty industry is now all about “wellness.” What does that mean for men?
content: The commercials are always the same: A razor is likened to a racecar or a jet. A shower gel purports to make men smell like a bear. There are also truly absurd ads for male hygiene products, one of which has a shirtless, brawny Terry Crews popping out of another man’s beard to urge him to shave using a cream made by Old Spice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Young Pianist Learns Liszt From Listening
description: For his new album, Benjamin Grosvenor delved into historical recordings of the daunting Sonata in B minor.
content: How do the great musicians prepare to play the great works? Each has his or her own methods, and tends to keep the strategy quiet, a secret key to success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo Accepts Some Blame in Nursing Home Scandal but Denies Cover-Up
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo admitted to a delay and that he “created pain,” but stopped short of a full apology for the state’s withholding of virus death data from state lawmakers.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Admitting a degree of fault for the first time, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that his administration’s lack of transparency about the scope of coronavirus-related deaths in nursing homes in New York was a mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Min Zin
title: Is Democracy in Myanmar Dead?
description: No. But the deposed government and its backers urgently need a concrete plan to foil the military’s divide-and-conquer strategy.
content: YANGON, Myanmar — Since the military seized power on Feb. 1, I have felt overwhelmed watching both the empowerment of a new generation of young protesters and a continuing failure of political leadership. I am torn between nostalgia and the urgent need for a concrete strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: With Indoor Rinks Closed, Players Turn to ‘Speakeasy Hockey’
description: In barns and backyards, outdoor rinks built with kits or from scratch are filling a void for hockey players amid pandemic-related closures.
content: NORTHVILLE, N.Y. — One by one, the hockey players drove down a dark road in the foothills of the Adirondacks in search of fresh ice on a recent Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: How Joe Neguse and Stacey Plaskett Plan to Wield Their Influence After Impeachment
description: Both representatives said they took note of their roles as among the few Black lawmakers who played a role in the historic proceeding.
content: WASHINGTON — From a corner of the Senate chamber last week, Delegate Stacey Plaskett, the congressional representative from the Virgin Islands, was struck by the poignancy of the scene in front of her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Decade After Arab Spring, Autocrats Rule Tattered Mideast
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 15, 2021.
content: “The younger generations saw what happened. It’s like a shark when they smell blood. Freedom is like this. We smelled it once, so we’ll keep trying.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Where Did the Dinosaur-Killing Impactor Come From?
description: A new study blames a comet fragment for the death of the dinosaurs 66 million years ago. But most experts maintain that an asteroid caused this cataclysmic event.
content: In one searing apocalyptic moment 66 million years ago, Earth was transformed from a lush haven into a nightmare world with a fiery wound that bled soot into the skies. The extraterrestrial object that slammed into our planet spelled doom for dinosaurs and countless other species, even as its fallout opened new niches to our mammal ancestors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Taylor Lorenz
title: Clubhouse, a Tiny Audio Chat App, Breaks Through
description: The 11-month-old app has exploded in popularity, even as it grapples with harassment, misinformation and privacy issues.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Robert Van Winkle, who is better known as the rapper Vanilla Ice, held court online last week with more than 1,000 fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Takes Center Stage With Ambitious Agenda as Trump’s Trial Ends
description: The president plans to quickly press for his $1.9 trillion stimulus bill, and then move on to infrastructure, immigration, climate change and other major priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s allies say that with the distraction of the impeachment trial of his predecessor now over, he will quickly press for passage of his $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief plan before moving on to an even bigger agenda in Congress that includes infrastructure, immigration, criminal justice reform, climate change and health care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Marie Fazio
title: At least 150 million Americans are in the storm’s path.
description: A sprawling winter storm pummeled a large swath of the United States on Monday, delivering heavy snowfall and icy conditions as temperatures plunged well below freezing.
content: A sprawling winter storm pummeled a large swath of the United States on Monday, delivering heavy snowfall and icy conditions as temperatures plunged well below freezing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Tom Stoppard’ Tells of an Enormous Life Spent in Constant Motion
description: Hermione Lee’s biography of the playwright and screenwriter covers his rigorous research and writing habits, his famous friends and his political thinking.
content: The Czech-born Jewish playwright Tom Stoppard arrived in England with his family in 1946, when he was 8. They’d managed to flee Czechoslovakia ahead of the Nazis, and had spent years in Singapore and in India. He’d later call himself a “bounced Czech.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Today
description: Take a moment to prepare for Mardi Gras, or embrace the cold weather and make a hearty stroganoff.
content: Good morning. Some are calling it Yardi Gras in New Orleans this year, since no one will be parading around on Fat Tuesday, but staying safe in their house floats instead. It might be good fun to join them for dinner tomorrow night, and if you have a day off today, you might use it to prepare a king cake for that meal’s dessert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Dana Rubinstein and Katie Glueck
title: Zoom Fatigue on the Campaign Trail: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race
description: The candidates in New York City can barely keep up with a dizzying schedule of online forums. One candidate joins from his closet.
content: Think you’re sick of Zoom calls? Try running for mayor of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Climate Activist Jailed in India as Government Clamps Down on Dissent
description: Disha Ravi, 21, is facing sedition charges, accused of sharing a Google Doc about the farmers protest with Greta Thunberg.
content: Before anyone outside her hometown knew her name, Disha Ravi spent four years raising awareness among young people in Bangalore about the effects of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Paul Nabhan and Austin Nuñez
title: Along the Southwest Border, Trump’s Wall Is Only One of the Insults He Left Behind
description: Here’s what Biden should do about the poverty, discrimination and environmental destruction.
content: President Biden has pledged that there will “not be another foot” of the Trump border wall built. But his first weeks in office demand more than stopping construction of the towering barricade that has fueled humanitarian crises and ravaged the desert environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Blue Lives Matter Is Over
description: Once the Trump mob attacked officers, Republican hypocrisy was exposed.
content: Blue Lives Matter is officially dead. People may continue to chant and post the slogan, but it is dead. Senate Republicans killed it last week when they voted to acquit Donald Trump of inciting an insurrection that left one officer dead and 138 injured. (Two officers who responded to the insurrection later died by suicide.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Ready or Not, Baseball Begins Spring Training This Week
description: Some things will be remarkably different — and others will get closer to normal — as M.L.B. and the players’ union continue to debate the sport’s future.
content: Steve Sparks is heading to spring training soon to broadcast the Houston Astros’ exhibition games on radio. But with the sport and the country still in the grip of the coronavirus, he will miss the up-close access that gives spring training its charm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: More than 3 million homes and businesses have lost power.
description: Millions of homes and businesses across the country were without electricity  Monday because of the destructive band of snow and ice that was forecast to extend for more than 2,000 miles.
content: Millions of homes and businesses across the country were without electricity  Monday because of the destructive band of snow and ice that was forecast to extend for more than 2,000 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan’s Growth Rebounds, but Virus-Related Weakness Looms
description: The world’s third largest economy capped off a terrible year with a sharp rise in activity. Still, analysts say trouble lies ahead.
content: TOKYO — Japan’s economy rebounded sharply in the last three months of 2020, government data showed Monday, extending its recovery from the coronavirus’s devastating impact in the first half of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elias E. Lopez
title: Johnny Pacheco, Who Helped Bring Salsa to the World, Dies at 85
description: A Dominican-born bandleader and songwriter, he co-founded Fania Records, known as the Motown of Salsa.
content: Johnny Pacheco, the Dominican-born bandleader who co-founded the record label that turned salsa music into a worldwide sensation, died on Monday in Teaneck, N.J. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: Hail Storms, Fiery Crashes and Takeout Meals: The Daytona 500’s Wild Sunday
description: Michael McDowell won NASCAR’s biggest race, and earned his first career win, after a late pileup took out the top contenders in front of him.
content: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — There was a 16-car pileup near the start of the afternoon race and another fiery one right before it ended shortly after midnight. In between, Sunday’s Daytona 500 had a bit of everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘In Cold Blood’ and ‘The Black Church’
description: Richard Brooks’s classic adaptation of Truman Capote’s “In Cold Blood” airs on TCM. And Henry Louis Gates Jr. looks at the history of African-American faith communities in a PBS documentary.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Pennsylvania G.O.P.’s Push for More Power Over Judiciary Raises Alarms
description: After fighting the election results, state Republicans are trying to increase their control of the courts. Outraged Democrats and good government groups see it as a new kind of gerrymandering.
content: When the Pennsylvania Supreme Court unanimously rejected a Republican attempt to overturn the state’s election results in November, Justice David N. Wecht issued his own pointed rebuke, condemning the G.O.P. effort as “futile” and “a dangerous game.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Give Dolly Parton a Statue Already
description: The Tennessee General Assembly’s vote to do so should be unanimous.
content: NASHVILLE — To call the Republican supermajority of the Tennessee General Assembly extremist is merely to state a fact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Dwayne Johnson Finds Room to Grow in ‘Young Rock’
description: The new NBC comedy, based on Johnson’s real life, chronicles him at three different ages on his journey to adulthood and stardom.
content: It’s hard to imagine Dwayne Johnson as anything other than the gargantuan, musclebound star of the “Fast and Furious” and “Jumanji” movie franchises, TV shows like “Ballers” and the professional wrestling ring, where he first came to prominence as the Rock. But he was once a smaller — or, at least, younger — man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: What to Do With a Day Off
description: Step 1: Remember to actually take the day off.
content: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: At 35, a Tennis Magician Brings Her Tricks to a First Quarterfinal
description: Hsieh Su-Wei’s overhead drop shots, wicked spins and two-handed shots can rattle her opponents.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The tennis court becomes a fun house mirror when the player across the net is Hsieh Su-Wei, the queen of the overhead drop shot, whose wicked spins, clever angles and two-handed shots from both sides can rattle her opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins, Melina Delkic, Karen Zraick and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: States in the U.S. are expanding access to vaccines. The supply isn’t keeping up.
description: Experts say expanding eligibility requires a delicate balance of prioritizing those most at risk and ensuring no dose goes to waste.
content: Racing to ramp up Covid-19 vaccinations, states have opened mass inoculation sites and expanded eligibility. But a big problem remains: The supply is not increasing quickly enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: America’s Other Forever War
description: The United States doesn’t just bomb its enemies. It chokes them.
content: “It is past time,” Joe Biden pledged last year, “to end the forever wars.” He’s right. But his definition of war is too narrow.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Sophie, Architect of Future Pop
description: Exploring the legacy of a producer and performer who imagined an approach to music without borders.
content: The artist perhaps most responsible for shaping the microgenre hyperpop was Sophie, the Scottish producer and performer who for much of the last decade made novel, chaotic, sweet and ingenious electronic music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: 3 Detectives Obtained a False Murder Confession. Was It One of Dozens?
description: Huwe Burton was wrongly convicted because of deceptive interrogation techniques. How many more cases were “solved” the same way?
content: For Huwe Burton, the breaking point came late on the night of Jan. 5, 1989, as he sat with detectives in a cramped, windowless room on the second floor of a Bronx police precinct. He had not eaten or slept much in 48 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: For ‘Buffy’ Fans, Another Reckoning With the Show’s Creator
description: Many fans said they are trying to reconcile accusations of misogyny against Joss Whedon, the creator of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” with their love of a show that celebrated female empowerment.
content: The Whedon Studies Association, a society of academics devoted to studying the works of Joss Whedon, is debating whether to change its name. Fans who grew up with his signature show, “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” and were planning to introduce it to their children are grappling with what to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder
title: In and Around Guadalajara, Homes Like Sanctuaries
description: As the Mexican city has grown into a creative epicenter, architects have built on the legacy of Luis Barragán, constructing residences that encourage introspection.
content: SEEN FROM ITS suburban street in Guadalajara, the capital of Jalisco state in western central Mexico, Casa Padilla looks less like a house than a monastery: a blank white wall marked with a broad crescent downspout and a plain cedar door. Barely seven feet high, the door opens into a small, shaded vestibule that ends in another door, this one leading to a bright, sunlit courtyard hemmed in by ecclesiastical walls. Straight ahead, a stairway encased in blush pink cantera stone disappears halfway through its rise behind another wall. With no clear destination, the steps become an abstraction, more sculpture than architecture. Beside the staircase and around a corner, another door opens into a dim foyer — a shock of darkness — leading to a short, labyrinthine corridor that ends, suddenly, in an expansive covered terrace, its 15-foot-high roof raised on a raft of pine beams, an archway framing the winding branches of a guamúchil tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: The Influence of a Perfect Teacher
description: Perhaps because I had a teacher who made reading aloud into ceremony, ritual and compelling drama, I grew up to find my cause in pediatricians’ promoting reading aloud at checkups.
content: “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” was published in 1964, so when my teacher read it aloud to my fourth-grade class, it was only a couple of years old. She had a good eye for a classic-to-be, did my fourth-grade teacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Freed From a Daily Commute, They Looked to the Suburbs
description: A larger, newer place in the couple’s West New York neighborhood was out of reach. But they didn’t need to be near the Lincoln Tunnel anymore.
content: During the past year, many renters, untethered from the office amid the pandemic, have traded an easy commute for more space. While some have made dramatic transitions, leaving cramped apartments for expanses of land upstate, others have made smaller moves — from Manhattan to Brooklyn or, in the case of one New Jersey couple, from the commuter town of West New York to the suburb of East Rutherford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill McKibben
title: How Does Bill Gates Plan to Solve the Climate Crisis?
description: In “How to Avoid a Climate Disaster,” the billionaire Microsoft founder lays out his concerns for the earth and some concrete ideas for the future.
content: HOW TO AVOID A CLIMATE DISASTERThe Solutions We Have and the Breakthroughs We NeedBy Bill Gates
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Mitch McConnell Is So Over Trump That He Voted to Absolve Him
description: On the impeachment front, it was an exciting — if sometimes perplexing — weekend.
content: Bret Stephens: What a wild week, Gail. Should we feel pleased that seven Republican Senators voted to convict Donald Trump of incitement — six more than in the last impeachment — or appalled that the other 43 didn’t?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: ‘We Can Bring Down the Regime’: Myanmar’s Protesting Workers Are Unbowed
description: Two weeks after the military took power in a coup, growing work stoppages are undermining the ruling generals’ attempt to assert authority over an angry population.
content: Myanmar’s coup leaders have called on hundreds of thousands of government employees — doctors, garbage collectors, electricity workers — to set their “emotion” aside, abandon their protests against the military and return to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Viet Thanh Nguyen
title: I Actually Like Teaching on Zoom
description: There may be less human warmth. But there can be more human connection.
content: Here’s an unpopular opinion: I like teaching on Zoom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Auction Offers Lincoln’s Hair and Other Presidential Oddities
description: The auction feeds a thriving market for private collectors. Among the items: photographs, a lottery ticket signed by Washington, a Kennedy sweater, and a check from Donald J. Trump.
content: Robert Russell Crans Jr. is storing a bounty of items once owned and touched by President Abraham Lincoln and his family that represent a time in American history and politics most can only read about in history books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: The W.H.O. formally authorizes the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine.
description: The World Health Organization on Monday authorized the use of the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, clearing a path for the cheap and easy-to-store shots to be distributed in lower- and middle-income countries around the world.
content: The World Health Organization on Monday authorized the use of the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, clearing a path for the cheap and easy-to-store shots to be distributed in lower- and middle-income countries around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Impeachment’s Over. Bring On the Criminal Investigations.
description: After Mitch McConnell’s cynical speech, Republicans can’t complain.
content: A few hours after the Senate voted in Donald Trump’s impeachment trial on Saturday, I spoke to the lead impeachment manager, Jamie Raskin. He was crushingly disappointed. Despite Republicans’ indulgence of Trump over the last five years, despite the fact that three Republican senators met with Trump’s lawyers before they presented their defense, Raskin had so much faith in the overwhelming case he and his colleagues brought that, until the end, he held out hope of conviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Strict hotel quarantines in Britain.
content: People flying into England from South Africa, Brazil and 31 other countries deemed by Britain to be hot spots for coronavirus variants now have to complete a 10-day quarantine in a government-sanctioned hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden and the Fed Leave 1970s Inflation Fears Behind
description: Administration and Fed officials argue that workers not getting enough stimulus help is a larger concern than potential spikes in consumer prices.
content: WASHINGTON — Presidents who find themselves digging out of recessions have long heeded the warnings of inflation-obsessed economists, who fear that acting aggressively to stimulate a struggling economy will bring a return of the monstrous price increases that plagued the nation in the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Deaths of Soldiers and Policemen Held by Kurdish Guerrillas Roils Turkish Politics
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan blamed the United States and opposition Kurdish politicians in an effort to deflect responsibility for a failed rescue operation.
content: ISTANBUL — Turks reacted with shock and anger Monday to the news that Kurdish guerrillas had executed 13 Turkish soldiers and police officers held captive in a cave in the mountains of northern Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Patrick J. Lyons
title: Utilities in 14 states are told to start rolling blackouts because of storm strains.
description: The Southwest Power Pool has ordered member electric utilities in 14 states to start controlled rolling cutoffs of electric service because the demand for power in the region, driven upward by the bitter cold, is overwhelming the available generation, hampered by the storm.
content: The Southwest Power Pool has ordered member electric utilities in 14 states to start controlled rolling cutoffs of electric service because the demand for power in the region, driven upward by the bitter cold, is overwhelming the available generation, hampered by the storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in California
description: An 1888 Victorian in Coronado, a Mediterranean-style home in Los Angeles and a new house in Redwood City.
content: This property includes two structures: the 1888 Thompson-Grotenstein House, recognized by the Coronado Historical Association as a landmark in 1984, and a 1910 Craftsman bungalow that serves as a guesthouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Taimoor Shah and Jim Huylebroek
title: The Taliban Close In on Afghan Cities, Pushing the Country to the Brink
description: The Taliban have positioned themselves around several major population centers, including the capital of Kandahar Province, as the Biden administration weighs whether to withdraw or to stay.
content: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — The Taliban have been encroaching on key cities around Afghanistan for months, threatening to drive the country to its breaking point and push the Biden administration into a no-win situation just as the United States’ longest war is supposed to be coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanne Derks
title: An Inside Look at Cuba’s Constant Struggle for Clean Water
description: Across the country, battling water scarcity requires a vast array of workers, from inspectors and fumigators to truck drivers and pipe layers.
content: In one hand Manuel Reyes Estrada carried a form and a pencil, in the other a bucket filled with small fish and a plastic Bucanero beer cup. “It is like this,” he said. “We, the health brigade employees, are only allowed to write with pencils.” His superiors, he explained, use pens. In the afternoon, the superiors visit the houses where the health brigade employees have worked earlier in the day — “to check if we have done our work well.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: W.T.O. Officially Selects Okonjo-Iweala as Its Director General
description: Dr. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the first woman and the first African to serve in the post, said she would make global economic recovery from the pandemic a priority.
content: WASHINGTON — The World Trade Organization on Monday officially selected Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, a Nigerian economist and former finance minister, to be its next leader. The first woman and first African to serve as director general, Dr. Okonjo-Iweala will assume the post on March 1 for a renewable term expiring on Aug. 31, 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: How Fast Are Those Australian Open Courts? Does It Matter?
description: Players are calling this the fastest Grand Slam tennis court they have played on. Technicians say the speed hasn’t changed. Who is right?
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The chatter about the speed of the tennis courts at the Australian Open this year started innocently enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Norman Golb, Dead Sea Scrolls Contrarian, Is Dead at 92
description: He challenged the conventional wisdom about a major archaeological discovery. He also led a successful effort to open it for study by a wide range of researchers.
content: In 1947, a young Bedouin shepherd stumbled across a cave one mile from the northwestern shore of the Dead Sea and discovered seven weathered parchment scrolls, some containing biblical texts in Hebrew, that dated as far back as 300 years before the birth of Jesus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: A Black Soldier’s Heroism, Overlooked in 1965, May Finally Be Lauded in 2021
description: Comrades repeatedly told the Army that Capt. Paris Davis, one of the first Black officers in the Special Forces, deserved the Medal of Honor. The Army kept losing the paperwork.
content: Capt. Paris Davis was in the thick of a pre-dawn raid on an enemy camp in Vietnam when a grenade blasted out several of his teeth and, more troubling, tore off part of his trigger finger. Then enemy fire started pelting the Special Forces team he commanded. His most experienced sergeant was shot down. Then the demolitions specialist. Then the only medic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Twitter Is Turning Birds Into Celebrities and Birders Against One Another
description: A Twitter account helped spread the word about rare birds in New York City, but publicizing their locations exposed a rift among birders.
content: In 2018 it was the Mandarin duck. Last October it was the barred owl. Just weeks ago it was the snowy owl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Scottish University Draws Ire for Dismissing Female Gender Studies Lead
description: The decision by the University of St. Andrews not to renew the contract of a female philosopher points to broader underrepresentation of women in academia, critics say.
content: Students, staff and academics across the world are voicing their indignation after the University of St. Andrews in Scotland failed to renew the contract of the female director of its Institute for Gender Studies, part of its philosophy department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Kathleen Ham, Who Met Her Rapist Twice in Court, Dies at 73
description: “He’s been out there for 32 years,” she said in a voice turned gravelly by years of chain-smoking. “And I’ve been in my own private jail.”
content: She saw something moving on her fire escape. In the next instant, a man smashed through her window and raped her at knifepoint. A neighbor heard her screams and called the police, who caught the assailant near her apartment in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan. At his trial in 1974, the jury deliberated for eight days without reaching a verdict, and he was let go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Harper
title: Ancient Rome Has an Urgent Warning for Us
description: The era of the Antonine Plague offers a reminder of what a powerful force nature has been throughout human history.
content: He was a child of privilege turned demagogue, a man who blurred the boundaries of politics and spectacle and seemed to think himself a divinity beyond mortal rules. His tumultuous tenure lasted longer than anyone expected. Then along came a pestilence that seemed a sordid reflection of the ruler’s arrogance and ineptitude. The disease revealed and amplified social tensions that had festered under the surface and brought back whispers of civil war. The people could stand no more, and even the fainthearted Senate at last showed hopeful signs of courage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: ‘Right Now Feels So Long and Without Any End in Sight’
description: More than 700 people have been keeping digital diaries as part of Pandemic Journaling Project. It may be the most complete record of our shifting moods in this isolating year.
content: Those thoughts, typed into a digital journal on May 30, could stand as an anthem for this tragic pandemic year, a cry recognized around the world without explanation or context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Ruth Dayan, Who Built an Israeli Fashion Brand, Dies at 103
description: Fusing social activism with style, she helped Jewish immigrants and local Arabs sell traditional crafts, leading to the formation of a fashion house.
content: Ruth Dayan, the ex-wife of the Israeli soldier-statesman Moshe Dayan and the founder of Maskit, a fashion house that expressed her social justice ideals by employing the artisanal traditions of Jewish immigrants and Arabs, died on Feb. 5 at her home in Tel Aviv. She was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Asher, Ben Horwitz and Toni Monkovic
title: Why Does Louisiana Consistently Lead the Nation in Murders?
description: It has problems common to several Southern states, like a high rate of poverty, but also an inheritance of violence.
content: For 31 straight years, Louisiana has reported the nation’s highest murder rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 Australian Open: What to Watch on Monday Night
description: Serena Williams, Naomi Osaka and Novak Djokovic are playing to reach the semifinals of the Australian Open.
content: How to watch: 6 to 9 p.m., Eastern time, on the Tennis Channel and 9 p.m. to 7 a.m. on ESPN2 in the United States; streaming on the ESPN+ and ESPN3 apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Walker
title: How Pandemic Lunches Gave Me Hope for the Planet
description: My daughter’s lockdown achievement is that she does not let food go to waste. It’s reminded me that humans don’t have to leave a mass of trash in their wake.
content: Leftovers. Leftovers may be the key to saving the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Adam Kinzinger’s Lonely Mission
description: Censured by his party and shunned by family members, Mr. Kinzinger, a six-term Illinois congressman, is pressing Republicans to leave Donald Trump behind — and risking his career doing so.
content: WASHINGTON — As the Republican Party censures, condemns and seeks to purge leaders who aren’t in lock step with Donald J. Trump, Adam Kinzinger, the six-term Illinois congressman, stands as enemy No. 1 — unwelcome not just in his party but also in his own family, some of whom recently disowned him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Brian M. Rosenthal
title: N.Y.C.’s subway system will start running longer into the night next week, officials say.
description: Subways in New York will soon resume running longer into the night, transit officials announced on Monday, marking a step toward the full reopening of city life amid the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Subways in New York will soon resume running longer into the night, transit officials announced on Monday, marking a step toward the full reopening of city life amid the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Barbecue, cat pictures and snowball fights: Texans grapple with winter.
description: Before last week, Texas wasn’t much known for dangerous winter weather, or for being well practiced at coping with it. More than 120 accidents were reported on slick roads in and around Houston Sunday night.
content: Before last week, Texas wasn’t much known for dangerous winter weather, or for being well practiced at coping with it. More than 120 accidents were reported on slick roads in and around Houston Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Shiffrin Wins Record Sixth World Championship Title
description: A gold medal in the women’s combined at Cortina made Shiffrin the most decorated American Alpine skier at the event. She has a chance for two more wins this week.
content: Mikaela Shiffrin cemented her claim as the best American Alpine skier ever by winning her record-breaking sixth world championship on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dodge
title: Meet the Women Who Become Surrogates
description: New York State will now allow gestational surrogates to carry babies for other parents. Here’s why they do it.
content: In 1995, Lisa Wippler, having recently retired from the Marines, moved with her husband and two young sons to Oceanside, Calif., and was contemplating her next chapter in life. The answer came while lying in bed one night, reading an article about infertility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Parler, a Social Network That Attracted Trump Fans, Returns Online
description: After being cut off by Amazon and other tech giants, Parler worked for weeks to find a way to get back on the internet.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Parler, the social network that drew millions of Trump supporters before disappearing from the internet, is back online a month after Amazon and other tech giants cut off the company for hosting calls for violence around the time of the Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Honoring Cicely Tyson, Harlem’s ‘Trueborn Queen’
description: Cicely Tyson lay in repose at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, where she had been a member for three decades.
content: The line began forming in the dark on Monday, hours before anyone would be allowed inside the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. One 86-year-old member of the church awoke at 4:30 a.m. to ensure that she would be one of the first people on the line. She was the third.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: A hand-written letter from several members of Rep. Adam Kinzinger’s family.
content: A hand-written letter from several members of Rep. Adam Kinzinger’s family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: 5 Recipes for Mardi Gras at Home
description: Mardi Gras looks a little different this year, but these recipes will help you get into the spirit.
content: Mardi Gras looks a little different this year, but these recipes will help you get into the spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3.2 Million in California
description: An 1888 Victorian in Coronado, a Mediterranean-style home in Los Angeles and a new house in Redwood City.
content: An 1888 Victorian in Coronado, a Mediterranean-style home in Los Angeles and a new house in Redwood City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Winter Storm Sprawls Across the U.S.
description: A major winter storm hit a large part of the United States, delivering heavy snowfall and causing power outages in many cities as temperatures plunged below freezing.
content: A major winter storm hit a large part of the United States, delivering heavy snowfall and causing power outages in many cities as temperatures plunged below freezing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Political Era Is Reborn
description: The son of the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. discusses his father’s theory of cycles in American politics. Also: Seeing the world in two.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Plight of Women in the Pandemic
description: Readers express gratitude for reporting on the difficulties of parenting and working, more profound in the lockdown.
content: To the Editor:
